JACK DANIELS AND 8 MILES –(A TRUE STORY)

4 June 2013
Journey Towards EnlightenmentRealtalkGames
By root
0 Comments

Me, in the ambulance jacket, lying on ‘magic rug’!

It started out as a quite night, just two mates and a bottle of jack somehow stranded at a park. My phone dead and nothing planned, two reckless teens refuting the system and negating institutionalised party systems. We set to the streets for a night that we knew we would remember for the rest of our days. Late night philosophy and bonding, that night two bros ventured through the most derelict suburbs of Perth and emerged as men.

“Nolan, Jeremiah Nolan!” there was no reply, yep we were stranded. What the hell happened? We weren’t entirely sure, waking up approximately fourteen kilometres from where we had begun (8.6) miles (according to Google maps), sleeping in a house rug on the beach. Our friend, whom which we counted on in these sorts of pickles was un-contactable in our one true time of need. Moving our positions and leaving our rug behind, we hobbled to Mindarie quay and collapsed outside ‘The boat’ bar/pub exhausted, early morning before it had opened. A passing man with a small dog grinned at us, “caugh! You got the right idea mate!” At this point, we lost it. We were certain that he had telepathically seen our night/morning of adventure and approved.

***

“shit, shit zone hot!”, we had sighted police. My mate and I ran for cover off the main road (god knows where) cowering in the darkest corner behind a bridge. This was a first person co-op adventure and we were the stars. We rationed and were very careful with our dosage of ‘fuel’. Too much under and this shit would get too real too quickly, too much over and we wouldn’t be going too far. This was a serious situation. After re-fuelling and waiting for the heat to cool off, we set off running into the side streets of Clarkson— “Clarkson station??!” How did we end up here? Both of us were baffled at the mileage we had already travelled.

On our walk we passed a peculiar house… this house had three different coloured dog bowls sitting affront. “hold the fence open”, my mate whispered to me, I did as requested, ‘awe man be careful, hurry up common!!” I replied anxiously. He entered the small front yard of the apartment looking house, carefully re-arranging the bowls colour order. “RUN RUN RUN!!!” he screamed as we both ran from the scene of the crime at full pelt, those people would be so pissed!!

Magic Rug

After venturing further through the darkness and unknown, running from shadows, running from shadows in the dark and performing brief workouts on crudely crafted public ‘striders’ and ‘peddle devices’, we came across some houses that must have been awaiting rubbish pickup.

“Hey, man, look at this!!” I shouted exuberantly, “keep it down man” my buddy countered, even louder. We were both gone. “aha! Check this out! Oh my god!!” It was an abandoned carpet rug! Such a treasure! I quickly snatched the corner of the rug and ran like hell.

In mid-flight, given my drunken state, I completely forgot that I was pulling the rug behind me.. “AHHHHHH AHHHHHHH AHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!” Screaming with horror at this mysterious carpet that was somehow chasing me, my mate was dying with laughter whilst trying to keep up with the absurdity and my lighting fast adrenaline-fuelled run. Later, we resolved the fact that I was not being perused.

Wrapping the rug and hoisting into unto our shoulders, we resolved that it would be a useful tool to combat the cold if we had to ‘close up shop’ for the night.

The Church & Supply drop

“A CHURCH!” Praise Jeremiah! Jeremiah the lord! At this moment we called our friend Jeremiah Nolan, who was typically our saviour in these situations. Calling him up, he responded, sounding very tired and nauseous. “ahhhhhh” is all I recall him moaning to us during the whole period. We mounted the stairs of the church, kneeling in front of the doors we gave our praise and gratitude to Nolan, begging for a supply drop. “Praise the Lord! Jeremiah!!” we called to the heavens, poor neighbours. Our friend soon hung-up and we continued the antics for some time after without realising our contact had been lost.

Leaving the church disheartened but still buzzing with alcohol induced excitement, we came across a rare treasure. “SUPPLY DROP! HE SENT US A SUPPLY DROP! PRAISE THE LORD!” A trolley! In the middle of know-where? It was a sign that we must pick up where our forefathers had left off. We were going to the beach.

We carefully placed magic rug into the wheeled cage beast. We took turns rolling the treasure, until, we came across the slopes of Mindarie. “Get in” my friend said to me, I quickly jumped in—and it was amazing! Rolling, watching the stars blur in my vision, feeling the wind in my face and the exhilaration. That night I felt what it was like to travel through time and space. We took turns at this and both had the time of our lives. Miraculously, we didn’t suffer any serious injuries.

Arriving at the beach we parked our beast just shy of the beach car-park, has a trolley ever been so far from home? I don’t know, in any case, it felt like a triumph. Finding a small quiet cove on the beach, we rolled out our enormous mite-infested rug and enjoyed the gentle sound of wave’s soothing us to sleep, along with a couple of drunk dials.

***

The world came to life the next day, people emerged from their homes and business and heat overcame the quay. After enjoying Dome breakfast and freaking out as we sat across the room from a pair of police officers (we still wonder to this day whether or not they were there on account of us), we came to the resolution that no one was coming to save us. It was up to us to save ourselves (insert inspirational quote about overcoming unbelievable odds here).

Wearing jeans and dressed for a club, we pick up all the stray supplies we could, lost sunnies and old hats we scrimmaged from the beach as we attempted to walk to the nearest appropriate bus stop (which was kilometers away). Dehydrated and after some walking, we stumbled over dunes and discovered an abandoned party area! It was filled with broken glass, old bottles and food scraps. Even a smashed computer! “What a disgrace!” we thought. How could anyone show that disrespect to a machine?

After some time and small talk about a “Sunday Sesh!” we comically repeated the phrase to each other in different accents. My favourite was a rich Canadian accent, the speech flowed magnificently “ITS SUNDAYYYY” I began, “WE’RE GONNNA HAVE A SESH”. This created hours of enjoyment on our journey back to the homestead. We didn’t care about the stares of small children, (understandable, we looked like drug addicts and sounded like lunatics) we were conquerors!

The close and the opening

One last bus ride home, sitting in the back after a light cafe meal (we scrimmaged together change) we sat exhausted, falling asleep. Enter unassuming pre-teen. The kid carried a skateboard in his right hand, we made the mistake of eye contact. Looking at us, his expression turned to one of disgust and hate as he aggressively threw his skateboard on the seat and angrily sat down. We found this hilarious and had no idea what had just happened. We made it to our respective homes at last, safe and sound. This was the end of one adventure, and the beginning of a legacy.
